YLBHI Desak Aturan Tak Adil di UU Bantuan Hukum Dicabut
02 Nov 2019, 13:50 by M Rosseno Aji, Amirullah
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - Yayasan Lembaga Bantuan Hukum Indonesia (YLBHI) menilai pemerintah belum mampu mewujudkan akses keadilan untuk masyarakat. Sejak diterbitkan pada 2 November 2009, menurut YLBHI, Undang-Undang Bantuan Hukum belum menjamin hak masyarakat untuk mendapatkan akses keadilan.
"Sewindu lahirnya UU Bantuan Hukum, pemerintah masih belum mampu mewujudkan akses keadilan," kata Ketua YLBHI Asfinawati dalam keterangan pers tentang lahirnya UU ini, Sabtu, 2 November 2019.
Asfinawati mengatakan permasalahan akses keadilan terjadi karena tiga hal. Pertama, masih adanya peraturan perundang-undangan yang menjadi sumber ketidakadilan. Sejumlah aturan itu, yakni beleid yang melegitimasi kriminalisasi hak beragama dan berekspresi, melegitimasi perampasan tanah rakyat, serta melegitimasi pencemaran dan perusakan lingkungan.
Kedua, Asfinawati juga menilai, masih adanya penyalahgunaan penegakan hukum, seperti penangkapan dan penahanan sewenang-wenang, penyiksaan dan, penggunaan kekerasan secara berlebihan. Selain itu, YLBHI juga mencatat masih terjadi kriminalisasi, pemerasan dan pungutan liar, korupsi peradilan dan diskriminasi layanan hukum.
Ketiga, menurut Asfinawati, YLBHI mendata masih ada upaya menghalangi pemberian bantuan hukum. Hal itu dilakukan oleh aparat, seperti mengintimidasi tersangka agar tidak menggunakan penasihat hukum, menutup akses pengacara kepada orang yang ditangkap, mengiming-imingi pemberian pasal atau putusan yang lebih ringan jika tidak menggunakan penasehat hukum.
Karena itu, di hari kelahiran UU Bantuan Hukum ini, YLBHI mengingatkan Pemerintah untuk melaksanakan mandatnya sesuai UU tersebut. Beberapa langkah yang harus dilakukan pemerintah yakni, mencabut atau merevisi berbagai peraturan perundang-undangan yang melegitimasi ketidakadilan; melakukan perubahan Kitab Undang-undang Hukum Acara Pidana dengan fokus meminimalisasi penyalahgunaan penegakan hukum; dan melakukan reformasi birokrasi penegakan hukum secara total dan sungguh-sungguh.

YLBHI Urges Unjust Regulations in the Legal Aid Act Revoked
02 Nov 2019, 13:50 by M Rosseno Aji, Amirullah
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - The Indonesian Legal Aid Foundation (YLBHI) believes that the government has not been able to realize access to justice for the community. Since it was published on November 2, 2009, according to YLBHI, the Law on Legal Assistance has not guaranteed the right of people to get access to justice.
"After the birth of the Law on Legal Aid, the government has not been able to realize access to justice," said YLBHI Chairman Asfinawati in a press statement about the birth of this law, Saturday, November 2, 2019.
Asfinawati said the problem of access to justice occurred because of three things. First, there are still laws and regulations that are a source of injustice. A number of these rules, namely the regulation which legitimizes the criminalization of the rights to religion and expression, legitimizes the seizure of people's land, and legitimizes environmental pollution and damage.
Secondly, Asfinawati also assessed that there is still abuse of law enforcement, such as arbitrary arrest and detention, torture and, excessive use of violence. In addition, YLBHI also noted that criminalization, extortion and extortion still occur, judicial corruption and discrimination in legal services.
Third, according to Asfinawati, YLBHI recorded there were still efforts to prevent the provision of legal aid. This was done by the authorities, such as intimidating suspects from using legal counsel, closing access to lawyers for those arrested, luring out giving articles or lighter decisions if they did not use legal counsel.
Therefore, on the day of birth of the Law on Legal Aid, YLBHI reminded the Government to carry out its mandate according to the Act. Some steps that must be taken by the government are to revoke or revise various laws and regulations that legitimize injustice; amend the Criminal Procedure Code with a focus on minimizing misuse of law enforcement; and reform the law enforcement bureaucracy totally and seriously.
